prompt_init: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to rephrase this text without modifying its meaning. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The winner of a Xiangqi, or Chinese chess, tournament has been stripped of his title after allegations of inappropriate behaviour.

Yan Chenglong has also been accused of cheating by using a communication device analogous to anal beads.

The 48-year-old has been stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

However, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it's impossible to prove accusations of cheating.

Xiangqi has been hugely popular across Asia for hundreds of years.

According to the CXA, Mr Yan started drinking with friends in his hotel room shortly after winning the title of "Xiangqi King" at a national tournament held on the Chinese island of Hainan last week.

He then defecated in the hotel bath in an act "that damaged hotel property and violated public order and good morals", said the CXA statement.

The CXA was forced to address rumours circulating online that Mr Yan had cheated using anal beads equipped with wireless transmitters to send and receive signals.

"Based on our understanding of the situation, it is currently impossible to prove that Yan engaged in cheating via 'anal beads' as speculated on social media," the CXA said.

As punishment for bad behaviour, Mr Yan was stripped of his title and banned from playing for a year.

The association did not disclose the amount of prize money Yan was forfeiting, but Xiangqi tournaments often promise winners tens of thousands of yuan (thousands of dollars), according to AFP.
stories: A Chinese chess champion has been stripped of his title and banned from competition for a year due to allegations of inappropriate conduct. Yan Chenglong, 48, was accused of cheating by using a wireless communication device, similar to anal beads, during a national tournament in Hainan, but the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) says it cannot prove these allegations. Instead, Yan was punished for his behavior after winning the title, including drinking with friends in his hotel room and causing damage to the hotel property by defecating in the bathtub. The CXA took away his title and banned him from playing for a year, also forfeiting his prize money, which can amount to tens of thousands of dollars in Xiangqi tournaments.

A prominent Chinese chess player has lost his championship title and faces a one-year competition ban following accusations of misconduct. Yan Chenglong, 48, was suspected of cheating during a national tournament in Hainan by using a wireless device, but the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) was unable to substantiate these claims. Instead, the CXA punished Yan for his behavior after securing the title, which included hosting a gathering with friends in his hotel room and causing damage to hotel property by defecating in the bathtub. As a result, Yan was stripped of his title, banned from competition for a year, and forfeited his prize money, which can reach tens of thousands of dollars in Xiangqi tournaments.

A well-known Chinese chess player, Yan Chenglong, 48, has been stripped of his championship title and banned from competing for a year due to allegations of misconduct. Although initially suspected of cheating during a national tournament in Hainan by using a wireless device, the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) could not prove these claims. However, Yan's behavior after winning the title, including hosting a gathering in his hotel room and causing damage to hotel property by defecating in the bathtub, led to his punishment. As a consequence, Yan lost his title, was barred from competition for a year, and had to forfeit his prize money, which can amount to tens of thousands of dollars in Xiangqi tournaments.

Yan Chenglong, a 48-year-old renowned Chinese chess player, has been penalized with a year-long competition ban and stripped of his championship title due to allegations of improper conduct. Initially, suspicions arose that Yan had cheated during a national tournament in Hainan by utilizing a wireless device, but the Chinese Xiangqi Association (CXA) was unable to substantiate these claims. Nevertheless, Yan's behavior following his title win, including organizing a hotel room gathering and vandalizing hotel property by defecating in the bathtub, ultimately led to his punishment. As a result, Yan forfeited his title, was barred from competing for a year, and lost his prize money, which can total tens of thousands of dollars in Xiangqi tournaments.
